Label: Raddish
Description:
Radish belongs to the family Brassicaceae which can be grown in all agro-climatic zones                                       Seed requirement:
5 kg/ha                                                                                         Land preparation:
Soils should be ploughed to a depth of 30-40 cm to provide the necessary depth and fine tilth.               Weed Control:
One hand weeding is enough after 2 weeks of planting   Harvesting:
Harvest when plants are at correct maturity stage (depend on the variety).Delayed harvesting reduces the quality of the harvest.                                                  Post-harvesting:
a) Grade roots and handle them carefully to avoid mechanical damage
b) Pack roots in well-ventilated containers for long distance transport

Label: Beet
Description:
Beet are grown well in cool temperature of up country area. It can be grown well in all the agro-ecological zones.                                                           Seed requirement
5-6 kg seeds /ha
Nursery Management
Add well decomposed organic manure to the raised beds. It is important to sterilization of the soil using fungicide, solar or burning paddy straws. Seeds are established in 10 cm apart rows.
Land preparation
Plough the land up to depth 30 cm and prepare the raise bed with 1 m width and 20 cm height
Planting
Seedlings are transplanted after 4-6 weeks. Water supply
Light, frequent irrigation is required especially at root elongation stage. Normally irrigate 3-4 day interval.
Weed Control
Manually control the weeds 2 weeks after transplants. Remove the weed before apply top dressing. Weeds are control with the intercultural operations as well.
Harvesting
Crop cab be harvest 75- 90 days after transplanting.

Label: Bitter Gourd
Description:
Bitter gourd is one of the popular vegetablesThis crop is having high medicinal value with anti diabetic and anti cancer propertis. Because of higher nutricious and medicinal value this crop is becoming a higher demanding crop                                                                                                        Seed requirement
6 kg/ha
Nursery Management
Nursery can be prepared in sand trays or beds. Seeds can be directly placed in nursery with well supply of water and sunlight. Plnta can be directly transferred from nursery to field directly within 10 days. If need more days, plants can be transferred to pots for another two weeks.
Land preparation
Plough 30 cm depth and make fine soil structure with small particles and hills should be 30m x30 x30m in size prepared filled composition with compost and surface soil.
Planting
Maha season : October to November
Yala season : April, May
Year round cultivation can be allowed for suitable areas
3 seeds per hill in 2-3 cm depth for direct seeding with recommended spacing. Prepared nursery plants can be established in the field with better time selections.
Trellising:  Three weeks after planting growing  plants can be trained to a mesh or stakes. Lateral branches at lower parts of the plants can be pruned.                                                                    Water supply
Need to keep crop with sufficient amount of soil water content. Water lodging will damage the plants. It is suitable to use soil cover to protect soil moisture during dry periods.

Label: Tomato
Description:
It is an important cash crop and also has a good potential for export. Tomato fruit rich in vitamin A, C and minerals.                                                                                                  Seed requirement
200-250 g/ha
Nursery Management
Suitable period for nursery establishment is mid of March or end of August. 1 m x 3 m size raised bed (about 15-20 cm raised) is recommended. Remove clods of earth and stubble. Mix well decomposed farmyard manure and top soil 1:1 ratio and lay on the bed to 5cm thickness.                                                                                                                Land preparation
Harrow the field deeper and break in to a fine soil. Mark planting holes according to given spacing and fill the holes with decomposed manure or organic matter (6-12 mt/ha).                                                                                                                                            Water supply
Don’t apply excess water specially in dry season. It causes fruit crack.
Weed Control
Always keep the cultivation free of weeds. It will reduce the risk of pest attack and disease infection.

Label: Capsicum
Description:
It is grow mostly in dry and intermediate zones. About 4000ha is cultivated annually and supply about 36000 mt. the per capita consumption is about 890g. the local need is satisfied with the local production                                                           Seed requirement
CA 8 – 1 kg/ha
HYW and LYW- 1.75 kg/ha
Nursery Management
3m x 90 cm and 15 cm height beds are prepared. Apply compost or cow dung 3-4 kg per square meter. Use burning, solar sterilization or agro chemicals to sterilize soils. Put seeds in rows 10-15 cm apart and less than to 1 cm depth                   .Land preparation
Plough the field up to 15-20 cm depth and two harrowings Raised beds have to be prepared for better drainage                                                             Water supply
Irrigation to be practiced in 4-5 day intervals at early stages and 1 week interval at latter stages of the crop. This depends on the rainfall. Irrigation required at before and after fertilizer application, and during flowering and fruit development stages.
Weed Control
Weeding is required at 2,4 and 8 weeks after planting fertilizer can be applied after weeding. Soils can be added to the plants after weeding and fertilizer application

Label: Pumpkin
Description:
Seed requirement
1 kg/ha
Land preparation
a) Plough to a depth of about 20-30 cm and harrow for fine tilth.
b)Make planting holes 30 x 30 x 30 cm
c) Add 5 kg organic matter per planting hole, mix with soil and heap to about 10 cm above ground level.
Planting
Plant after heavy rains.
a) Local Strains and A.N.K.
i) Dibble 4 seeds/planting hole (10 cm between seeds)
b)Butternut
i) Seeds with high germination – 2 seeds/hill
ii) Seeds with low germination – 3 seeds/hill
iii)Thin to 2 plants/hill 2 weeks after emergence
iv)To avoid adverse effects of unfavourable weather conditions seedlings can also be raised in polythene bags or Noridoko nurseries                                                    Water supply
a) For irrigation or drainage purposes make shallow drains 25 cm away from the planting hill.
b) Irrigate daily until germination is complete and every 7 days thereafter
C)Irrigate until beds come to field capacity, taking care not to submerge vines.
Weed Control
Hand weed and apply a straw mulch 3 weeks after gerination

Soil: rich humus well drained carbonic Soil

a) For irrigation or drainage purposes make shallow drains 25 cm away from the planting hill.
b) Irrigate daily until germination is complete and every 7 days thereafter
C)Irrigate until beds come to field capacity, taking care not to submerge vines.
Weed Control
Hand weed and apply a straw mulch 3 weeks after gerination

Label: Pumpkin
Description:
Seed requirement
1 kg/ha
Land preparation
a) Plough to a depth of about 20-30 cm and harrow for fine tilth.
b)Make planting holes 30 x 30 x 30 cm
c) Add 5 kg organic matter per planting hole, mix with soil and heap to about 10 cm above ground level.
Planting
Plant after heavy rains.
a) Local Strains and A.N.K.
i) Dibble 4 seeds/planting hole (10 cm between seeds)
b)Butternut
i) Seeds with high germination – 2 seeds/hill
ii) Seeds with low germination – 3 seeds/hill
iii)Thin to 2 plants/hill 2 weeks after emergence
iv)To avoid adverse effects of unfavourable weather conditions seedlings can also be raised in polythene bags or Noridoko nurseries                                                    Water supply
a) For irrigation or drainage purposes make shallow drains 25 cm away from the planting hill.
b) Irrigate daily until germination is complete and every 7 days thereafter
C)Irrigate until beds come to field capacity, taking care not to submerge vines.
Weed Control
Hand weed and apply a straw mulch 3 weeks after gerination

Label: Beans
Description:
Bean belongs to the family Fabaceae and Genus PhaseolusBean varieties can be categorized into two types based on their growth habit as vine types or “pole bean” and bush types or “Bush bean”. Vine types are the most popular among farmers and consumers as well. Pole bean varieties grow continuously and need supports (stakes) to grow upright. Pods are bigger in size and light in color. Bush beans doesn’t produce much yield and pods are dark green. Its normally cultivate as an intermediate crop between two main cropping seasons                                                                                                         Seed requirement
Vine type – 50kg/ha
Bush type- 75kg/haLand preparation
Plough soils to make fine tilth and prepare beds which can accommodate three rows. Mark planting holes in recommended spacing.
Planting
Soak seeds for about 24 hrs. before planting. Plant about 3-4 seeds per planting hole fairly away from each other. Keep beds well-watered. Two weeks after germination, keep two healthy seeding per planting hole and remove the other seedlings.                                   Water supply
Maintaining soil moisture at the optimum level during flowering and fruiting stages will assure higher yield. Therefore, supplementary irrigation has to be provided if the rainfall is insufficient.
Weed Control
Keep the cultivation weed free to reduce pests, diseases and competition of plants and weeds for nutrient and space.

Label: Squash
Description:
These crops may be grown to an elevation of 500 m in the dry and intermediate zones. While squash can be grown in either Maha or Yala.Harvesting
Harvest when fruit develops a powdery film.
1 pumpkin
a)A.N.K. – Harvest 40 days after flowering
b) Local Variety – Harvest 60days after flowering
2 Butternut – harvest 20 days after flowering
 
Yield
 Average yeilds for all varieties vary from 15,000 – 20,000 kg/ha
Post-harvest
a) Pumpkins can be stored for 6 – 8 months
b) Butternut can be kept for about 1 month under ambient conditions

Label: Snake Gouard
Description:
Originated in tropical Asian countries . Found in  South and Southeast Asia, including India , Bangladesh , Nepal , Pakistan , Sri Lanka , Indonesia , Malaysia , Burma and southern china.                                                     Seed requirement
4kg/ha
Nursery Management
Direct planting of seeds in the field
Land preparation
Plough the land 20-30 cm depth. 30 x 30 x 30 cm holes are prepared with recommended spacing
Planting
Add organic matters and fill the holes. Plant 2 seeds in one hole, with 2-3 cm depth seed germinate starts within 5 – 8 days                                                                               Water supply
Daily irrigate the crop until seed germinate
Weed Control
Control weeds at the early stages of the crop
Harvesting
Harvest the crop 60-75 days after planting with 4 days interval

Soil: Well drained Carbonic Loamy Sandy Soil
Label: Ridged Gouard
Description:
Ridge gourd/ sponge gourd (Wetakolu) is a very popular crop belonging to family Cucurbitaceae
It can be cultivated in all over the low country, mid, country wet zone and Intermediate Zones, as an economical cropsSeed requirement
3 kg /ha
Land preparation
Harrow the soil and break the soil finely and mark pits to recommended spacing. Make several deep drains to avoid excess water retention in field.
Planting
Soak the seeds in water for about 24 hours. Plant about 3-4 seeds per pit, fairly away from each other. Keep the seeds well watered.

Soil: Well drained Carbonic Loamy Clay Soil
Label: Winged  Beans
Description:
Description:
Winged beans (Psophocarpus tetragonolobus) are highly nutritious legumes known for their four-winged pods. They thrive in tropical climates and are rich in protein, vitamins, and minerals. Almost all parts of the plant, including pods, leaves, flowers, and roots, are edible.
Seed Requirement:
Requires 8-10 kg of seeds per hectare.
Seeds have a hard coat and need pre-soaking in water for 24 hours or scarification to improve germination.
Land Preparation:
Choose well-drained, fertile loamy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.0.
Plow the field 2-3 times to make the soil loose and well-aerated.
Incorporate organic manure or compost for better soil fertility.
Planting:
Sow seeds in rows with a spacing of 50-60 cm between rows and 30-40 cm between plants.
Use trellising or staking for better growth and higher yields.
Best planting time is at the beginning of the rainy season.
Water Supply:
Requires moderate but consistent watering, especially during the germination and flowering stages.
Avoid waterlogging, as it can cause root rot.
Weed Control:
Perform regular hand weeding or mulching to suppress weed growth.
Use shallow hoeing to avoid damaging roots.
Organic or chemical weed control methods can be used as needed.

Soil: Well drained Carbonic Loamy Clay Soil
Label: Winged  Beans
Description:
Description:
Winged beans (Psophocarpus tetragonolobus) are highly nutritious legumes known for their four-winged pods. They thrive in tropical climates and are rich in protein, vitamins, and minerals. Almost all parts of the plant, including pods, leaves, flowers, and roots, are edible.
Seed Requirement:
Requires 8-10 kg of seeds per hectare.
Seeds have a hard coat and need pre-soaking in water for 24 hours or scarification to improve germination.
Land Preparation:
Choose well-drained, fertile loamy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.0.
Plow the field 2-3 times to make the soil loose and well-aerated.
Incorporate organic manure or compost for better soil fertility.
Planting:
Sow seeds in rows with a spacing of 50-60 cm between rows and 30-40 cm between plants.
Use trellising or staking for better growth and higher yields.
Best planting time is at the beginning of the rainy season.
Water Supply:
Requires moderate but consistent watering, especially during the germination and flowering stages.
Avoid waterlogging, as it can cause root rot.
Weed Control:
Perform regular hand weeding or mulching to suppress weed growth.
Use shallow hoeing to avoid damaging roots.
Organic or chemical weed control methods can be used as needed.

Label: Chilli
Description:
Description:
Chili (Capsicum spp.) is a widely grown spice crop known for its pungent flavor. It is used in fresh, dried, or powdered form in various cuisines. Chili plants thrive in warm climates and well-drained soils, with different varieties ranging from mild to extremely hot.
Seed Requirement:
Requires 1-1.5 kg of seeds per hectare for direct sowing.
For nursery raising, 150-200 g of seeds per hectare is sufficient.
Seeds should be treated with fungicide to prevent seed-borne diseases.
Land Preparation:
Choose fertile, well-drained sandy loam soil with a pH of 6.0–7.0.
Plow the land 2-3 times and incorporate well-decomposed organic manure.
Create raised beds or ridges to improve drainage and aeration.
Planting:
Seeds can be directly sown or transplanted from a nursery after 30-35 days.
Maintain a spacing of 45-60 cm between rows and 30-45 cm between plants.
Best planting season is during spring or the onset of monsoon.
Water Supply:
Chili plants need moderate but consistent watering, especially during flowering and fruiting.
Avoid overwatering, as chili plants are sensitive to root rot.
Drip irrigation is recommended for better moisture control.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding or use mulching to suppress weed growth.
Shallow hoeing helps remove weeds without damaging roots.
Pre-emergence herbicides can be used if necessary for large-scale farming.

Label: Kankun
Description:
Description:
Water spinach (Ipomoea aquatica), also known as kangkong, is a fast-growing, semi-aquatic leafy vegetable. It thrives in warm, humid climates and is commonly cultivated in both dryland and water-based systems. The plant is rich in vitamins A and C, iron, and fiber.
Seed Requirement:
Requires 8-10 kg of seeds per hectare for direct sowing.
Seeds should be soaked in water for 12-24 hours before planting to improve germination.
Land Preparation:
Prefers moist, well-drained loamy or sandy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.5.
For dryland cultivation, plow the soil 2-3 times and add organic manure.
For water-based cultivation, ensure a shallow water level and good water flow.
Planting:
Sow seeds directly in the soil or propagate using stem cuttings.
Maintain spacing of 20-30 cm between rows and 10-15 cm between plants.
Can be grown year-round but prefers warm and humid conditions.
Water Supply:
Requires frequent watering, especially in dryland cultivation.
Keep the soil moist but not waterlogged for healthy growth.
In water-based cultivation, maintain a water depth of 5-10 cm.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding or use mulching to suppress weed growth.
In water-based cultivation, weeds can be controlled by adjusting water levels.
Regular harvesting helps reduce weed competition naturally.

Label: Mukunuwenna
Description:
Mukunuwenna is the commercially grown and most popular leafy vegetable type in the market. This is popular due to its nutritional, medicinal and characteristic flavor. The crop is rich in vitamins, calcium and iron                                          1.Vine type
2.Bushy typeLand preparation
Raised beds for low lands (paddy fields) and sunken beds for highlands are more suitable.
Soil is ploughed and allowed weeds to decompose. Then the fields are filled with water and take a fine filth and levelled. Drains are prepared to facilitate the drainage.
Planting
Stem cuttings are planted in specified spacing or randomly. Single cutting is planted at one point.  Water supply
Irrigation is done frequently to maintain the moisture at the top layer of the bed. Water lodging should be avoided.
Weed Control
During the land preparation weeds should be controlled as much as possible. Hand weeding should be practiced throughout the cropping cycle

Label: Gotukola
Description:
Because of its characteristic specific flavor. It has medicinal values and rich in iron. Therefore it has high market demand.There are two types of Gotukola based on its growth habit
1.Bush type
2.Vine Type
There are three types of vine type Gotukola according to the size of leaves.
1.Type with large leaves (Giant Gotukola)
2.Type with medium size leaves (Meerigama selection). This is the most commercially grown Gotukola type and taste is good
3.Types with small leaves (WelGotukola)                                 Land preparation
Raised beds or sunken beds should be prepared according to the selected field to facilitate good drainage. Good textured soil with fine filth is more suitable for the growth of deep roots
Planting
Runners should be planted according to the specified spacing. Organic manure should be mixed with soil before planting. soil should be well moist when planting. Avoid drying of beds by covering with cadjans.                                          Water supply
Irrigation is important to maintain the soil moisture. Water logging should be avoided
Weed Control
Weed should be controlled to maintain quality of harvest and to reduce spreading pest and disease.

Label: Sweet Potato
Description:
Originated in southern American Tropical countries. Cultivated throughout the year with irrigation easy management due to low input requirement, short duration and low pests and disease problems. Land preparation
Plough the land about 25 cm depth. Hence Soil aeration and good drainage is facilitated.
Planting
However, vegetative growth is high in yala with good irrigation.   Water supply
At the crop initial growth stage water supply is important.
Excess water reduces tuber production
Weed Control
It is important to remove weeds at early stage of the crop, to reduce plant competition.

Planting
However, vegetative growth is high in yala with good irrigation.   Water supply
At the crop initial growth stage water supply is important.
Excess water reduces tuber production
Weed Control
It is important to remove weeds at early stage of the crop, to reduce plant competition.

Label: Spinach
Description:
A green leafy vegetable rich in Iron. It contains oxalic acid which prevents the body from absorbing Calcium. Therefore, the calcium in the blood is not absorbed into the bones and may accumulate in the kidneys and bladder and deposited there.eed requirement
10 – 15 grams of seeds is required per 10m2 bed. (10-15g / 10m2 bed)
Field preparation and planting
Weeds should be controlled and the ground should be ploughed well and the soil should be finely prepared. It is important to improve drainage by placing raised beds in areas where water logged. It is advisable to plant two seeds in one place. It takes about 5-6 days for the seeds to germinate.Water supply/Irrigation
Irrigate the crop well every 3-4 days. In dry weather it is advisable to irrigate the crop more often without allowing them to wither.
Weed Management
Weeds should be removed and the field should be kept clean as long as the crop remains.

Label: Turmeric
Description:
Description:
Turmeric (Curcuma longa) is a tropical rhizomatous plant widely used as a spice and medicinal herb. It thrives in warm, humid conditions and well-drained soil. The underground rhizomes are rich in curcumin, which gives turmeric its distinct yellow color and health benefits.
Seed Requirement:
Requires 2,500–3,000 kg of rhizomes per hectare for planting.
Use disease-free, healthy rhizomes (preferably with 1-2 buds) for better germination.
Land Preparation:
Choose well-drained loamy or sandy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.5.
Plow the field 2-3 times and mix in well-decomposed organic manure or compost.
Raised beds or ridges are recommended to improve drainage.
Planting:
Rhizomes are planted at a depth of 5-7 cm, with a spacing of 45-60 cm between rows and 20-30 cm between plants.
Best planting time is at the onset of monsoon (April–June) for optimal growth.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially during the vegetative stage.
Avoid overwatering to prevent rhizome rot; drip irrigation is beneficial.
Reduce watering as the crop matures to enhance rhizome development.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding at regular intervals.
Use organic mulching (e.g., dry leaves, straw) to suppress weeds and retain moisture.
Pre-emergence herbicides can be applied if necessary for large-scale farming.

Label: Ginger
Description:
Description:
Ginger (Zingiber officinale) is a perennial spice crop known for its aromatic rhizomes. It thrives in warm, humid climates and well-drained soils. Ginger is widely used in cooking, medicine, and as a flavoring agent in beverages.
Seed Requirement:
Requires 1,500–2,000 kg of rhizomes per hectare.
Select disease-free, healthy rhizomes with 1-2 buds for planting.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained loamy or sandy soil with a pH of 5.5–6.5.
Plow the land 2-3 times and add well-decomposed organic manure.
Raised beds or ridges help prevent waterlogging and promote healthy growth.
Planting:
Plant rhizomes 5-7 cm deep, with a spacing of 30 cm between rows and 20-25 cm between plants.
The best planting season is early spring or pre-monsoon (March–June).
Water Supply:
Requires regular irrigation, especially during the vegetative stage.
Avoid waterlogging, as excess moisture can cause rhizome rot.
Reduce watering gradually as the crop matures to improve rhizome quality.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding at regular intervals.
Use mulching with dry leaves or straw to suppress weed growth and retain moisture.
Organic or chemical weed control can be applied if necessary.

Label: Kathurumurunga
Description:
It belongs to the legume family (Fabaceae). It is a leafy vegetable that can be grown easily and a valuable medicinal herb. It can be grown without applying agrochemicals.Planting Materials
By Seeds  and stem cuttings
By seeds:
Seeds should be obtained from freshly ripened pods that have turned yellow. Nurseries are prepared in large soil blocks, polythene bags, paper bags and other containers can be used to produce seedlings from seeds. Several seeds are sown in these containers, allow to emerge and one healthy seedling is allow to grow removing rest of the seedlings. About 15-20cm healthy seedlings are suitable for field planting.
Layering- Remove a 1cm wide bark from branches that having pencil thickness and moistened coir dust is kept around that place and using  a transparent polythene it is tied (layering). After about 3-4 weeks when the roots are growing, the branch is separated from the plant and it is suitable for field planting as a new plant.
Stem cutting :
Stem cuttings can be rooted and field planting in “Haritha “ variety.Land preparation & Planting
45x45x45cm3  size planting holes are prepared; add compost or organic matter and mix with the topsoil and prepared seedlings or rooted cuttings are planted. They should be exposed to the sun for a few days and hardened before field planting.Water supply
In dry weather, irrigation can be practiced to obtain more harvest
Weed Control
Weeds should be controlled and  keep the crop clean.

It belongs to the legume family (Fabaceae). It is a leafy vegetable that can be grown easily and a valuable medicinal herb. It can be grown without applying agrochemicals.Planting Materials
By Seeds  and stem cuttings
By seeds:
Seeds should be obtained from freshly ripened pods that have turned yellow. Nurseries are prepared in large soil blocks, polythene bags, paper bags and other containers can be used to produce seedlings from seeds. Several seeds are sown in these containers, allow to emerge and one healthy seedling is allow to grow removing rest of the seedlings. About 15-20cm healthy seedlings are suitable for field planting.
Layering- Remove a 1cm wide bark from branches that having pencil thickness and moistened coir dust is kept around that place and using  a transparent polythene it is tied (layering). After about 3-4 weeks when the roots are growing, the branch is separated from the plant and it is suitable for field planting as a new plant.
Stem cutting :
Stem cuttings can be rooted and field planting in “Haritha “ variety.Land preparation & Planting
45x45x45cm3  size planting holes are prepared; add compost or organic matter and mix with the topsoil and prepared seedlings or rooted cuttings are planted. They should be exposed to the sun for a few days and hardened before field planting.Water supply
In dry weather, irrigation can be practiced to obtain more harvest
Weed Control
Weeds should be controlled and  keep the crop clean.

Description:
Brinjal is considered as a highly marketable nutritious cropSeed requirement
350g/haLand preparation

Label: nol khol
Description:
A vegetable belongs to cabbage family which is cultivated as an annual. Most cultivated as a mix crop with other vegetablesSeed requirement
Short duration varieties – 600 – 750 g/ha
Long duration varieties – 375 – 400 g/haLand preparation and Planting
Fine land should be prepared by ploughing and leveling without weeds. 3 -4 weeks old seedlings with 8 – 10 cm height ae suitable for planting in holes prepared according to the recommended spacing. 250 seedlings can be produced by 1 g of knol-khol seeds.Water supply/ Irrigation
Maintenance of well moist soil is important. Knobs can be cracked if irrigate when soil is too dry.
Weed Control and earthing up
Hand weeding can be practiced at 2 – 3 weeks after transplant. Collect soils to the base of plant at 4-5 weeks.

Label: Cassava
Description:
Good starchy food source. Considerable amount of calcium, Phosphorus and vitamin C is rich in roots. Use as staple food as well as chips, alcohol and fuel productivity. Comparatively low water and nutrient requirement. Therefore thrive well in marginal lands.Land preparation
Tillage and plant on set of rain
Planting
In wet zone plant in both Yala and Maha season. In Dry Zone plant in Maha season
Single holes or Ridges can be used.
Bag cultivation of cassava can be observed in different locations. In this method, 50 kg polysacks filled with loam soil are used.Water supply
At the early stage water supply or soil moisture is important.
Weed Control
Weed Control is important in the beginning of the crop until crop cover the ground

Label: Guava
Description:
Description:
Guava (Psidium guajava) is a tropical fruit tree known for its high nutritional value and medicinal properties. It thrives in warm climates and is rich in vitamin C, fiber, and antioxidants. Guava trees are hardy, drought-tolerant, and can be grown in various soil types.
Seed Requirement:
Guava is mainly propagated through seeds, grafting, or air layering.
If using seeds, they should be soaked in water for 24 hours to enhance germination.
Grafted or air-layered plants bear fruit earlier than seed-grown trees.
Land Preparation:
Requires well-drained loamy or sandy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.5.
Plow the field 2-3 times and mix in organic manure or compost.
Dig pits of 60 cm × 60 cm × 60 cm, spaced 5-6 meters apart for optimal growth.
Planting:
The best planting time is during the monsoon or early spring.
Transplant healthy seedlings or grafted plants into prepared pits.
Water immediately after planting and apply mulch to retain moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially in dry seasons and during flowering.
Avoid waterlogging, as it can lead to root rot.
Drip irrigation is recommended for better moisture control.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding around the base of the plant regularly.
Use organic mulching (e.g., dry leaves, straw) to suppress weeds and retain soil moisture.
Light hoeing can be done to aerate the soil and prevent weed growth.

Label: Mangoostenes
Description:
Mangosteen (Garcinia mangostana), known as the ""Queen of Fruits,"" is a tropical fruit prized for its sweet, tangy flavor and high antioxidant content. It requires a warm, humid climate and grows best in well-drained soils with high organic matter.
Seed Requirement:
Propagated mainly by seeds, as grafting is difficult.
Requires 250-300 seeds per hectare for planting.
Seeds should be fresh, as they lose viability quickly.
Land Preparation:
Prefers deep, well-drained loamy or sandy soil with a pH of 5.5–6.5.
Plow the land 2-3 times and add organic manure or compost.
Dig planting pits of 60 cm × 60 cm × 60 cm, spaced 8-10 meters apart.
Planting:
Best planted at the beginning of the rainy season.
Place seeds or seedlings in the pits and cover with nutrient-rich soil.
Water immediately and apply mulch to retain moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires consistent watering, especially in dry seasons.
Avoid waterlogging, as mangosteen is sensitive to root rot.
Drip irrigation is recommended for maintaining adequate soil moisture.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding around the base of the tree regularly.
Use mulching (dry leaves, straw, or coconut husks) to suppress weed growth and retain soil moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and control weeds.

Label: Avacado
Description:
Description:
Avocado (Persea americana) is a nutrient-rich fruit known for its creamy texture and high healthy fat content. It thrives in warm, tropical to subtropical climates and requires well-drained soil for optimal growth. Avocado trees can live for decades and produce fruit for many years.
Seed Requirement:
Propagation is done using seeds, grafting, or air layering.
Grafted trees bear fruit earlier (3-5 years) than seed-grown trees (5-10 years).
Spacing: 8-10 meters apart to allow proper canopy development.
Land Preparation:
Requires well-drained loamy or sandy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.0.
Plow the land 2-3 times and mix in organic manure or compost.
Dig pits of 60 cm × 60 cm × 60 cm and leave them open for 2-3 weeks before planting.
Planting:
The best planting time is at the beginning of the rainy season.
Place seedlings or grafted plants in prepared pits and cover with soil.
Water immediately and apply mulch to retain moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially during dry periods and fruit development.
Avoid waterlogging, as avocado roots are prone to rot.
Drip irrigation is recommended for better moisture management.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding around the base of the plant regularly.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or grass) to suppress weeds and retain soil moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and control weed growth.

Drip irrigation is recommended for better moisture management.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding around the base of the plant regularly.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or grass) to suppress weeds and retain soil moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and control weed growth.

Label: Avacado
Description:
Description:
Avocado (Persea americana) is a nutrient-rich fruit known for its creamy texture and high healthy fat content. It thrives in warm, tropical to subtropical climates and requires well-drained soil for optimal growth. Avocado trees can live for decades and produce fruit for many years.
Seed Requirement:
Propagation is done using seeds, grafting, or air layering.
Grafted trees bear fruit earlier (3-5 years) than seed-grown trees (5-10 years).
Spacing: 8-10 meters apart to allow proper canopy development.
Land Preparation:
Requires well-drained loamy or sandy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.0.
Plow the land 2-3 times and mix in organic manure or compost.
Dig pits of 60 cm × 60 cm × 60 cm and leave them open for 2-3 weeks before planting.
Planting:
The best planting time is at the beginning of the rainy season.
Place seedlings or grafted plants in prepared pits and cover with soil.
Water immediately and apply mulch to retain moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially during dry periods and fruit development.
Avoid waterlogging, as avocado roots are prone to rot.
Drip irrigation is recommended for better moisture management.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding around the base of the plant regularly.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or grass) to suppress weeds and retain soil moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and control weed growth.

Soil: Well drained Carbonic Loamy Sandy Soil
Label: Watermelon
Description:
Description:
Watermelon (Citrullus lanatus) is a warm-season fruit known for its juicy, sweet flesh and high water content. It thrives in hot, sunny climates and requires well-drained soil for optimal growth. Watermelons are rich in vitamins A and C and provide excellent hydration.
Seed Requirement:
Requires 3-5 kg of seeds per hectare.
Hybrid seeds improve yield and disease resistance.
Seeds should be treated with fungicide before sowing to prevent diseases.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained sandy loam soil with a pH of 6.0–7.5.
Plow the field 2-3 times and mix in organic manure or compost.
Raised beds or ridges help improve drainage and root development.
Planting:
Best planting season is spring to early summer, when temperatures are warm.
Sow seeds 2-3 cm deep, with spacing of 1-1.5 meters between rows and 60-90 cm between plants.
Direct seeding or transplanting seedlings can be used.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially during flowering and fruit development.
Avoid overwatering, as it can lead to fruit cracking and disease.
Drip irrigation is ideal for maintaining consistent soil moisture.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding or use mulching (plastic mulch, straw, or grass) to suppress weeds.
Shallow hoeing helps control weeds without damaging roots.
Pre-emergence herbicides can be used if necessary for large-scale farming.

Label: Papaya
Description:
Description:
Papaya (Carica papaya) is a fast-growing tropical fruit tree valued for its sweet, nutrient-rich fruit. It is high in vitamin C, antioxidants, and digestive enzymes. Papaya thrives in warm, humid climates and is grown for both fresh consumption and commercial processing.
Seed Requirement:
Requires 250-300 grams of seeds per hectare.
Hybrid or hermaphrodite varieties are preferred for higher yields.
Seeds should be soaked in water for 24 hours before planting to enhance germination.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained loamy or sandy soil with a pH of 6.0–7.5.
Plow the land 2-3 times and mix in organic manure or compost.
Dig planting pits of 60 cm × 60 cm × 60 cm, spaced 2-3 meters apart.
Planting:
Best planted at the onset of the rainy season.
Direct seeding or transplanting 30-40 day-old seedlings is common.
Plant 3-4 seedlings per pit and later retain the healthiest one.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially during flowering and fruiting.
Avoid waterlogging, as papaya roots are sensitive to excess moisture.
Drip irrigation is recommended for efficient water use.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding around the base of the plant.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or grass) to suppress weeds and retain soil moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and control weed growth.

Label: Karapincha
Description:
Description:
Curry leaves (Murraya koenigii) are aromatic leaves widely used in cooking and traditional medicine. The plant is a small to medium-sized tree that thrives in warm, tropical climates and requires minimal maintenance once established.
Seed Requirement:
Requires 500-700 grams of seeds per hectare.
Fresh seeds (removed from ripe fruits) have better germination rates.
Can also be propagated through stem cuttings or root suckers for faster growth.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained loamy or sandy soil with a pH of 6.0–7.5.
Plow the land 2-3 times and mix in organic manure or compost.
Dig pits of 30 cm × 30 cm × 30 cm, spaced 1.5-2 meters apart.
Planting:
Best planting time is early monsoon or spring season.
Sow seeds directly or transplant 30-45 day-old seedlings.
Water immediately after planting and apply mulch to retain moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially in the initial growth stage.
Once established, curry leaf plants are drought-tolerant and need watering only during dry periods.
Avoid waterlogging to prevent root rot.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding around the base of the plant regularly.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or compost) to suppress weeds and retain moisture.
Light hoeing helps improve aeration and control weed growth.

Label: Rampe
Description:
Description:
Pandan (Pandanus amaryllifolius) is a fragrant tropical plant widely used in cooking, herbal medicine, and natural flavoring. It is a hardy, low-maintenance plant that grows well in warm, humid climates and can be cultivated in pots or open fields.
Seed Requirement:
Propagated mainly through stem cuttings rather than seeds, as seeds are rare.
Use 10–15 cm long cuttings with a few roots for better growth.
Spacing: 50–60 cm apart for proper air circulation.
Land Preparation:
Prefers moist, well-drained loamy or sandy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.5.
Plow the land 1-2 times and mix in organic compost or manure.
Raised beds are ideal in areas prone to waterlogging.
Planting:
Best planting time is during the rainy season for natural moisture.
Plant cuttings directly in the soil, ensuring at least 5 cm of the stem is buried.
Water immediately after planting and apply mulch to retain moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, as pandan prefers moist soil.
Avoid complete drying out but also prevent waterlogging.
Drip irrigation is beneficial for consistent moisture levels.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding around the plants regularly.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, coconut husks, or compost) to suppress weeds and retain moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and prevent excessive weed growth.

Label: Cinnamon
Description:
Description:
Cinnamon (Cinnamomum verum or Cinnamomum cassia) is an evergreen tree cultivated for its aromatic bark, which is widely used as a spice and in traditional medicine. It thrives in tropical climates with well-drained soils and high humidity.
Seed Requirement:
Propagated mainly through seeds, stem cuttings, or air layering.
Fresh seeds should be sown immediately, as they lose viability quickly.
Requires 500–800 seedlings per hectare, depending on spacing.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained sandy loam or clay loam soil with a pH of 5.5–7.0.
Plow the land 2-3 times and mix in organic manure or compost.
Dig pits of 30 cm × 30 cm × 30 cm, spaced 2.5–3 meters apart.
Planting:
Best planting time is at the beginning of the rainy season.
Transplant 6-month-old seedlings or plant cuttings directly in prepared pits.
Water immediately and apply mulch to retain soil moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially in the first 2 years of growth.
Once established, cinnamon trees are drought-resistant but benefit from occasional irrigation.
Avoid waterlogging, as it can lead to root diseases.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding around the base of the plant regularly.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or wood chips) to suppress weeds and retain moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and control weed growth.

Label: Cinnamon
Description:
Description:
Cinnamon (Cinnamomum verum or Cinnamomum cassia) is an evergreen tree cultivated for its aromatic bark, which is widely used as a spice and in traditional medicine. It thrives in tropical climates with well-drained soils and high humidity.
Seed Requirement:
Propagated mainly through seeds, stem cuttings, or air layering.
Fresh seeds should be sown immediately, as they lose viability quickly.
Requires 500–800 seedlings per hectare, depending on spacing.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained sandy loam or clay loam soil with a pH of 5.5–7.0.
Plow the land 2-3 times and mix in organic manure or compost.
Dig pits of 30 cm × 30 cm × 30 cm, spaced 2.5–3 meters apart.
Planting:
Best planting time is at the beginning of the rainy season.
Transplant 6-month-old seedlings or plant cuttings directly in prepared pits.
Water immediately and apply mulch to retain soil moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially in the first 2 years of growth.
Once established, cinnamon trees are drought-resistant but benefit from occasional irrigation.
Avoid waterlogging, as it can lead to root diseases.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding around the base of the plant regularly.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or wood chips) to suppress weeds and retain moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and control weed growth.

Label: Okra
Description:
A crop belonging to family Malvaceae. Easy to grow and can be grown in throughout the year, making it popular among farmers.Consumes young pods, but leaves are a delicacy in India and Africa. Nutrient level is very high, fibres, minerals, especially calcium and Iodine are presence in immature pods. Okra plays an important role in controlling thyroxine related disease since calcium and iodine availability is high.Seed requirement
4.5 kg/ha
Land preparation
Harrow the soil and break soil finely. Mark pits according to given spacing; fill the pits with decomposed organic matter. Make several drains to avoid water retention / loggingWater supply/ Irrigation
Irrigate twice a day until seeds are germinated. After that irrigation should be practiced according to moisture condition in the soil
Weed Control
When plants are young, remove weeds by hand around the plants. Always keep the cultivation free of weeds. It will reduce the risk of pests and diseases.

Label: Pepper
Description:
Description:
Black pepper (Piper nigrum) is a tropical climbing vine cultivated for its dried fruit, which is used as a spice. Known as the ""King of Spices,"" it thrives in warm, humid climates and requires support for climbing.
Seed Requirement:
Propagated mainly through stem cuttings rather than seeds.
Requires 1,500–2,000 cuttings per hectare.
Cuttings should be 30–50 cm long with at least 3-4 nodes for better growth.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained loamy or clayey soil with a pH of 5.5–6.5.
Plow the land 2-3 times and enrich it with organic manure.
Provide support structures (e.g., trees, poles, or trellises) for vines to climb.
Planting:
Best planted at the beginning of the rainy season.
Dig pits of 50 cm × 50 cm × 50 cm, spaced 2-3 meters apart.
Plant cuttings near support structures and tie them gently.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially in dry periods.
Avoid waterlogging, as pepper plants are prone to root diseases.
Drip irrigation is recommended for moisture control.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding regularly around the base of the plant.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or coconut husks) to suppress weeds and retain moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and prevent excessive weed growth.

Label: Innala
Description:
Description:
Baby potatoes are young, small-sized potatoes harvested before full maturity. They have a thin, tender skin and a slightly sweeter taste. They thrive in cool climates and require well-drained, loose soil for proper tuber development.
Seed Requirement:
Requires 600–1,000 kg of seed potatoes per hectare.
Use certified disease-free seed tubers for better yield.
Cut larger seed potatoes into smaller pieces, ensuring each has at least one eye.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained sandy loam or loamy soil with a pH of 5.0–6.5.
Plow the land 2-3 times and mix in organic manure or compost.
Create raised beds or ridges to improve drainage and aeration.
Planting:
Best planting time is early spring or late summer in temperate climates.
Plant seed tubers 5–10 cm deep with 25–30 cm spacing between plants and 60–75 cm between rows.
Cover with loose soil and water immediately.
Water Supply:
Requires consistent moisture, especially during tuber formation.
Water every 3-5 days, depending on soil moisture levels.
Avoid overwatering, as it can cause rot and fungal diseases.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding or use a shallow hoeing method to avoid damaging tubers.
Apply mulching (straw, dry leaves, or grass clippings) to suppress weed growth and retain moisture.
Earthing up (mounding soil around the base) helps protect tubers from sunlight and weeds.

Label: Thibbatu
Description:
Description:
Thibbatu (Solanum torvum), also known as Turkey Berry, is a small, hardy shrub that produces clusters of small green fruits. It is commonly used in cooking and traditional medicine due to its nutritional and medicinal benefits. It grows well in tropical and subtropical climates.
Seed Requirement:
Requires 250–300 grams of seeds per hectare.
Seeds should be soaked in water for 24 hours before sowing to improve germination.
Can also be propagated through stem cuttings for faster growth.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained loamy or sandy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.5.
Plow the land 2-3 times and mix in organic manure or compost.
Dig pits of 30 cm × 30 cm × 30 cm, spaced 1.5–2 meters apart.
Planting:
Best planting time is at the beginning of the rainy season.
Sow seeds directly or transplant 30-45 day-old seedlings.
Water immediately after planting and apply mulch to retain moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially in dry seasons.
Water 2–3 times per week, ensuring the soil remains moist but not waterlogged.
Drip irrigation is recommended for better water management.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding around the base of the plant.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or compost) to suppress weeds and retain moisture.
Light hoeing helps improve aeration and control weed growth.

Label: Sarana
Description:
Description:
Sarana spinach (Boerhavia diffusa), also known as Punarnava, is a nutritious leafy green vegetable commonly grown in tropical and subtropical regions. It is valued for its medicinal properties and thrives in warm, well-drained soils.
Seed Requirement:
Requires 3–4 kg of seeds per hectare.
Seeds should be soaked in water for 12–24 hours before sowing to improve germination.
Can also be propagated through stem cuttings for faster growth.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained loamy or sandy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.5.
Plow the land 2–3 times and mix in organic manure or compost.
Create raised beds or rows, leaving 20–30 cm spacing between them for proper air circulation.
Planting:
Best planted at the beginning of the rainy season.
Sow seeds directly in the soil at a depth of 1–2 cm with 20–30 cm spacing between plants.
Water immediately after planting and apply mulch to retain soil moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially during the germination and growth stages.
Keep the soil moist but avoid waterlogging.
Drip irrigation is beneficial for maintaining consistent moisture levels.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding regularly around the plants.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or grass clippings) to suppress weeds and retain moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and prevent excessive weed growth.

Label: Kohila
Description:
Kohila leaves and rhizomes are popular and nutritious foods. It is good for hemorrhoids and stomach aches as it is rich in fiber.There are two types of kohila.
Local kohila: The leaf is not divided into many segments. Growth is slow and yields are low. Rhizomes are relatively small and less fleshy.
Exotic Kohila: The leaf is divided into many segments. It shows higher growth rate and higher yield. Rhizomes are larger than the local variety and it is fleshy.Water supply/ Irrigation
Although moisture is required in the crop, prolonged exposure to water impairs growth. Therefore, necessary steps should be taken to irrigate the crop from time to time.
Weed Control
The main problem of kohila cultivation is the difficulty of weed control. After planting the shoots or buds, apply straw as a mulch to cover the ground. Weeds can also be controlled by applying mulch from time to time at different stages of the cultivation.

Label: Thumba Karawila
Description:
Although it is a vine, belongs to the bitter gourd family, it has no bitter taste and is a food that is having medicinal value for diabetes and stomach ailments.Seed requirement
Required 6000 healthy female seedlings and 1000 male seedlings in the ratio of 6: 1 per hectare and 6000 healthy female seedlings and 600 male seedlings in the ratio of 10: 1. Both fruiting and flowering vines are required for fruiting.
Land preparation
Turn the soil to a depth of 20-30 Cm and crush the pebbles. Fill 30x30x30 cm deep pits with organic manure and top soil.Water supply
Provide adequate water to maintain suitable soil moisture for cultivation.
Weed Control
At a young age, uproot the weeds near the seedlings and then shovel them so as not to damage the base.

Label: Lime
Description:
Description:
Lime (Citrus aurantiifolia or Citrus latifolia) is a small citrus tree that produces tangy, vitamin C-rich fruits. It thrives in warm, tropical, and subtropical climates and is widely used for culinary, medicinal, and beverage purposes.
Seed Requirement:
Propagated mainly through grafting, budding, or air layering rather than seeds for better yield.
If using seeds, select disease-free seeds, soak for 24 hours, and plant in a nursery before transplanting.
Requires 200–300 grafted plants per hectare with proper spacing.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained sandy loam or loamy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.5.
Plow the land 2-3 times and mix in organic compost or farmyard manure.
Dig planting pits 50 cm × 50 cm × 50 cm, spaced 4–6 meters apart.
Planting:
Best planting time is spring or early monsoon season.
Transplant healthy 6–12-month-old grafted seedlings into prepared pits.
Water immediately after planting and apply mulch to retain soil moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially during dry periods and fruiting stages.
Water once every 3–7 days, depending on soil moisture levels.
Avoid waterlogging, as citrus roots are sensitive to excess moisture.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding regularly around the base of the plant.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or grass clippings) to suppress weeds and retain soil moisture.
Light hoeing helps improve aeration and control weed growth.

Prefers well-drained sandy loam or loamy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.5.

Water immediately after planting and apply mulch to retain soil moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially during the dry season and fruiting stages.
Water once every 5–7 days, depending on soil moisture levels.
Drip irrigation is beneficial for maintaining consistent moisture levels.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding regularly around the base of the plant.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or grass clippings) to suppress weeds and retain moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and control weed growth.

Dig planting pits 50 cm × 50 cm × 50 cm, spaced 5–6 meters apart.
Planting:
Best planting time is spring or the beginning of the rainy season.
Transplant 6–12-month-old grafted seedlings into prepared pits.
Water immediately after planting and apply mulch to retain soil moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially during the dry season and fruiting stages.
Water once every 5–7 days, depending on soil moisture levels.
Drip irrigation is beneficial for maintaining consistent moisture levels.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding regularly around the base of the plant.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or grass clippings) to suppress weeds and retain moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and control weed growth.

Label: Rambutan
Description:
Description:
Rambutan (Nephelium lappaceum) is a tropical fruit tree native to Southeast Asia, known for its hairy red or yellow fruit with juicy, sweet flesh. It thrives in warm, humid climates and requires deep, fertile soil with good drainage.
Seed Requirement:
Propagated mainly through grafting, budding, or air layering for better fruit quality.
If using seeds, plant fresh seeds within 1-3 days as viability decreases quickly.
Requires 150–250 grafted plants per hectare with proper spacing.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained loamy or sandy soil with a pH of 5.0–6.5.
Plow the land 2-3 times and enrich it with organic manure or compost.
Dig planting pits 50 cm × 50 cm × 50 cm, spaced 8–10 meters apart due to wide canopy growth.
Planting:
Best planting time is early rainy season for good root establishment.
Transplant grafted or air-layered seedlings into prepared pits.
Provide shade for young plants and mulch around the base for moisture retention.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially in dry seasons.
Water every 3–5 days for young plants and every 7–10 days for mature trees.
Avoid waterlogging, as it can cause root rot.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding regularly around the base of the plant.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or coconut husks) to suppress weeds and retain soil moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and improve nutrient absorption.

Label: Pani Dodam

Description:
Sweet orange (Citrus sinensis) is a widely grown citrus fruit known for its sweet and juicy flesh. It is rich in vitamin C and antioxidants, thriving in warm, subtropical to tropical climates with well-drained soil.
Seed Requirement:
Propagated mainly through grafting or budding for high fruit yield and disease resistance.
If using seeds, select fresh, disease-free seeds, soak them for 24 hours, and germinate in a nursery before transplanting.
Requires 200–400 grafted plants per hectare, depending on spacing.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained sandy loam or loamy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.5.
Plow the land 2-3 times and mix in organic compost or farmyard manure.
Dig planting pits 50 cm × 50 cm × 50 cm, spaced 5–6 meters apart.
Planting:
Best planting time is spring or the beginning of the rainy season.
Transplant 6–12-month-old grafted seedlings into prepared pits.
Water immediately after planting and apply mulch to retain soil moisture.
Water Supply:
Requires regular watering, especially during dry seasons and fruiting stages.
Water once every 5–7 days, depending on soil moisture levels.
Drip irrigation is beneficial for maintaining consistent moisture levels.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding regularly around the base of the plant.
Use organic mulching (dry leaves, straw, or grass clippings) to suppress weeds and retain moisture.
Light hoeing helps aerate the soil and control weed growth.

Label: Carrot
Description:
Description:
Carrot is a root vegetable known for its crisp texture and high beta-carotene content, which converts to vitamin A. It thrives in cool climates with loose, well-drained soil.
Seed Requirement:
Requires 4–6 kg of seeds per hectare.
Use fresh, high-quality seeds for better germination.
Seeds should be sown directly into the field as carrots do not transplant well.
Land Preparation:
Prefers well-drained sandy loam or loamy soil with a pH of 5.5–7.0.
Plow the land 2-3 times and mix in organic manure or compost.
Create raised beds with fine, loose soil to encourage straight root development.
Planting:
Best planted in cooler seasons (15–25°C is ideal).
Sow seeds directly in rows at a depth of 1–2 cm with 20–30 cm row spacing.
Thin seedlings after 2-3 weeks to maintain 5–8 cm spacing between plants.
Water Supply:
Requires consistent moisture, especially during germination and root development.
Water 2–3 times per week, ensuring the soil remains moist but not waterlogged.
Drip irrigation is ideal to prevent soil compaction.
Weed Control:
Perform manual weeding or light hoeing regularly to prevent competition.
Use mulching (straw, dry leaves, or grass clippings) to suppress weed growth and retain soil moisture.
Avoid deep hoeing, as it can damage developing roots.
